texts.shortText: A small to medium-sized, beige-coloured cladobranch covered with many broken longitudinal white ridges. The head has an oral veil with a white margin. The rhinophores are short, white and set close together at their bases. The notum is pale to beige-coloured and may be darker at the centre. The notum has an indistinct white marginal band. The gills are located between the mantle and the foot. The foot is also beige with an indistinct white marginal band.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to the Eastern Cape, endemic, 10–80 m in depth.
This species has been found in deep water trawls but it is also seen in shallow water on sand. Individuals have been observed burrowing.
The species is thought to feed on sea pens.
This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon colour and shape not yet known.

Armina gilchristi can be confused with the Pink-and-white pinstripe, Dermatobranchus albineus, but is distinguished by its broken longitudinal ridges; and also with the Brown-patched pinstripe, Dermatobranchus arminus, but is distinguishable by its lack of brown patches.

Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 109).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 428).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 75).
